course_title: Making of Modern America: U.S. Since 1877
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 25 / Seats Avail: 25Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
(Same as AMST 285 2)


Between the end of Reconstruction and the early twenty-first century the United States became a great power and developed the strongest and wealthiest economy in the history of the world. This course will follow the nation's transformation from a farmers' republic to an industrial giant, demonstrating the interplay between its democratic institutions, its dynamic capitalist economy, and its diverse population.  Themes include immigration, transport, political reform, changing ideas about gender and sexuality, the two world wars, the "rights" revolution of the 1950s and 1960s, the Cold War, and the United States' emergence as the sole post-Cold War superpower.  Classes will be a mixture of lecture and discussion of assigned readings, with an emphasis on student participation.  There will be two papers, a midterm, and a final exam. 
Requirement Designation: Social Sciences
course_description: The course introduces the social, political, economic, and diplomatic forces that have shaped modern America. Special emphasis on how diverse components of the American population have interacted in American society.
